docs.title: What is diaphragm?
docs.text:
• In structural engineering, a diaphragm is a horizontal structural element — usually a floor slab or roof deck —
  • diapharm transfers lateral loads (like wind or earthquake forces) to the vertical resisting elements such as shear walls, braced frames, or moment-resisting frames.

docs.title: Types of diaphragm
docs.text:
• Rigid
  • diaphragm with infinite stiffness
  • In ETABS we usually go with rigid diaphragm to reduce computation time
  • In ETABS horizontal forces will get applied at center of mass
  • Semi Rigid
  • diaphragm with finite stiffness
  • With semi-rigid diaphragm we need to provide stiffness but in reality it provides similar results to rigid diapharms

docs.title: What is it?
docs.text:
• In normal analysis, geometry of structure don't change when applying forces.
  • So Internal forces are computed using original geometry.
  • But in reality, when structure deflects, loads act on deformed shape, producing secondary moment and increased stresses.
  • This is called P-Delta effect \(M = P \times \Delta\) , here P = Axial load acting on structure and Delta = Lateral displacement
  • P-Delta Analysis is extremely important in case of tall buildings where there is large amount of lateral drift or structure with slender columns or frames or structure with high flexibility
  • seismic or wind-loaded buildings are also affected by this.

docs.title: Types of P-Delta effects
docs.text:
• GLobal P-Delta effect
  • Overall lateral sway of the entire structure
  • for example wind load on tall building
  • Local P-Delta effect
  • Local bending of individual members
  • Column bending between floors

docs.title: How Modern software deals with it?
docs.text:
• All the modern software like ETABS, SAP2000 and STAAD Pro supports P-Delta analysis.
  • This software first runs first order analysis and then calculates additional movements using deflections.

docs.title: What is it?
docs.text:
• It's This is a fundamental concept in structural analysis to estimate how building or structure will respond to round motion using earthquake.
  • In simple terms it will tell you that, If building had certain stiffness and damping, how much it will shake during specific earthquake.

docs.title: How to use it?
docs.text:
• IT's graph of Time period vs max acceleration for Specific Structure Stiffneess at specific earthquake
  • So using this graph you can get max acceleration at specific time frame
  • we can use this max acceleration to calculate seismic force for our building

{: .note } In practice we don't need to generate this graph manually, we can use design code which gives use response spectrucm based on location and soil type

docs.title: ShearWall
docs.text:
• Vertical structure in building to resist lateral forces
  • These later forces can be wind loads, earthquake loads, or sometimes ground pressure.
  • Transfer Loads directly to foundation

docs.title: Purpose
docs.text:
• Resit Lateral loads
  • Reduce swaying due to wind or earthquake.
  • Increase Stiffness
  • Makes structure more rigid
  • reduce horizontal deflection, story drift, Vibration and shaking
  • Prevent structural failure
  • They prevent overturning, sliding, soft storey collapse
  • Partially Carry Gravity loads
  • Support Floor loads, wall loads, roof loads specially when placed around lift and staircases

docs.title: Placement
docs.text:
• Around lift cores
  • Around Staircase cores
  • Buildign parameter
  • Some more places to avoid torsion

docs.title: When we need it?
docs.text:
• High rise buildings
  • Building in earthquake zones
  • Building with large openings (Glass Facade)
  • Structures with irregular geometry
